Title.evidence: This study evaluated the early effects of tourniquet and/or ACB usage on quadriceps strength following TKA.

Trial_Design.evidence: Primary, elective TKA patients were assigned to one of four groups based on whether they received an ACB and/or tourniquet.

Participants.evidence: Primary, elective TKA patients were assigned to one of four groups based on whether they received an ACB and/or tourniquet.

Intervention.evidence: Primary, elective TKA patients were assigned to one of four groups based on whether they received an ACB and/or tourniquet.

Objective.evidence: This study evaluated the early effects of tourniquet and/or ACB usage on quadriceps strength following TKA.

Method_Outcome.evidence: We prospectively measured bilateral, isometric knee extension strength preoperatively and within 36 hours postoperatively.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Primary, elective TKA patients were assigned to one of four groups based on whether they received an ACB and/or tourniquet.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Measurements were collected for 203 patients: 68, 45, 45, and 45 in the tourniquet/ACB, tourniquet/ no ACB, ACB/no tourniquet, and no tourniquet/ no ACB groups, respectively.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Tourniquet use was associated with shorter operative time (p=0.004), while ACB use was associated with longer lengths of stay (p=0.005).
